awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  Genomics in a colonial setting
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates how European colonization in the Americas shaped the genetic diversity and shifting demographic and social practices within settler populations. Although numerous studies have explored the effects of European colonialism on indigenous populations, less is known about the effects of colonization on the settlers themselves. This study combines archaeological, ethnohistorical, and genetic analyses to document changes in population structure and genetic demography in a population of colonial settlers and their modern-day descendants.  The project will advance our understanding of how biological and social identities emerged in the colonial Americas, and also will expand the currently very limited colonial-era genomic data from the Americas.  This project provides training in archaeological and anthropological genetic methods and research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students, and supports community and public science outreach. 

This study uses next-generation sequencing techniques, target capture, and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) arrays to assess genome-wide diversity and genetic ancestry in individuals excavated from the St. George's Caye cemetery and from contemporary Belizeans who trace at least one genealogical lineage back to 18th century British Honduras. The genetic data generated will be used to answer questions about the genetic ancestry of the populations, the degree of population continuity and change, and whether or not genetic inferences of identity reflect archaeological and self-reported understandings of identity in colonial and contemporary contexts.  The project merges diverse research methodologies to shed light on the processes of identity formation and ethnogenesis in colonial contexts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
European colonization of the Americas significantly impacted population demography and genetic diversity in native and immigrating human populations. To assess the immediate and lasting impacts of colonialism on human genetic variation, we examined the genetic demography of a population of 18th century British colonists in the Bay of Honduras and their modern-day descendants. Genome-wide diversity and genetic ancestry were evaluated for individuals buried in the historic cemetery at St. George?s Caye and for contemporary Belizeans with genealogical ties to the historic population in the Bay. We evaluated these genetic data alongside ongoing archaeological and ethnohistoric research to clarify the effect of colonialism over time. Because genetic research of colonialism in the Americas tends to focus on colonized populations instead of the colonizers, this research has contributed a novel perspective on the effects of colonialism by targeting a British settler population for analysis.

We found significant differences in interpretations of colonial identity generated by archaeological, genetic, and archival research. While archival documents and local knowledge suggest the colonial residents of St. George?s Caye included both British colonists and enslaved African laborers, those sources indicate that the cemetery was used almost exclusively by the British colonists during the 18th century. In contrast, archaeological analysis demonstrated the presence of African cultural artifacts within some graves, suggesting that at least some of the community that were buried in the cemetery maintained some form of African identity. Genetic analyses of the mitochondrial (mtDNA) genome also demonstrated greater biological diversity in the cemetery than was reported in historical documentation or by local knowledge. However, genetic data often did not correlate with archaeological signals of cultural affinity on an individual level (e.g. individuals with African cultural artifacts did not necessarily have an African mtDNA lineage). These analyses have contributed to a more complete understanding of how identity may have been biologically and socially expressed in the historic population. Additionally, by employing diverse research methodologies, this project has drawn attention to details that can be overlooked when analyses are over-reliant on one methodological agenda, thereby challenging research programs that are built on singular methods to take a more integrative approach to knowledge production.

An additional portion of this project concerned characterizing the genetic demography of contemporary Belizeans with genealogical roots in the 18th century Bay Settlement. Our work has shown that the contemporary Belizean participants have very diverse genetic ancestry, both as individuals and as a group. Most individuals share genetic affinities with more than one of our selected global reference populations, indicating that their genetic ancestry is likely derived from multiple sources. Distinct patterns of mtDNA variation between the historic and contemporary groups indicated that there has been significant population discontinuity along the maternal line in Belize since the colonial establishment of British settlements, most likely as a result of additional immigration in the past few hundred years.

The research completed in this project and undertaken in partial fulfillment of the co-PI?s doctoral work has provided the co-PI with advanced professional development in computation biology and lab methods. This project has also enabled the training of several undergraduate and graduate students in genetic sampling techniques, ancient DNA laboratory methods, and computational analysis. As part of this work, personalized genetic ancestry reports have been generated for, and returned to, each of the contemporary Belizeans study participants. This project has allowed current members of the Belizean public to learn about their personal genetic ancestry while also raising awareness of the social-genetic interactions that have shaped the current Belizean community. The results of this project have been presented at several scientific meetings in the US and abroad, and have been disseminated to the local Belizean community in conjunction with local archaeological reports and village newsletters. Multiple manuscripts describing the results of this study are currently in preparation for submission to peer-reviewed journals for publication.
